FIRSTNAME : Jung;

UTEID :  jey283;
CSACCOUNT : jungyoon;
EMAIL : jungyoon@utexas.edu;


***********************************************************************************


---------------------------------------------------  
---------> NOTES
---------------------------------------------------  
ASSUMPTIONS -->
* program assumes that frequenciesFile is in correct format and only lists integers

RUNNING ---> 
* normal run format: java Encoder frequenciesFile k
* extra credit run format: java Encoder frequenciesFile k j (explained further below)

EXTRA CREDIT --->
* did both parts for a max of 2pts
* explained in full detail below 


***********************************************************************************


---------------------------------------------------  
---------> EXTRA CREDIT (2 PTS)
---------------------------------------------------   
1) Build the functionality so that, upon supplying an integer parameter j > 1, 
your system will automatically generate an encoding on the "j-symbol derived 
alphabet," i.e., taking sequences of j symbols at a time. Note, you are already 
building functionality to allow encoding j = 2 successive symbols.
********* PLEASE RUN IN FORMAT: java Encoder frequenciesFile k j
- frequenciesFile: name of a file containing integers representing the relative frequencies of characters
- k: a positive integer that tells how many characters to generate 
- j: integer > 1 to generate an encoding on the j-symbol derived alphabet
********* 

2) Using a large quantity of English text as your "reference file," compute the 
probabilities of characters (in the text). I'd suggest ignoring any non-letters 
and ignoring case. Generate an efficient encoding for this alphabet. Then use the
encoding on your reference text (ignoring non-letters and case). Compute the actual
efficiency of your encoding. In your README, explain how well you think this 
approximates the entropy of English.

----------------------
----------------------
FILE 1 (CONFUCIUS)
----------------------
----------------------

********* OUTPUT START ------->
Reading from file: THE GREAT LEARNING by Confucius (Size: 17,426 bytes)

******************************
**** EXTRA CREDIT PART 2: ****
******************************
SYMBOL	WEIGHT	HUFFMAN CODE
G	278	00000
F	282	00001
W	292	00010
M	304	00011
T	1344	001
C	323	01000
U	325	01001
R	728	0101
Y	194	011000
B	209	011001
D	496	01101
A	911	0111
N	918	1000
S	947	1001
E	1920	101
H	949	1100
O	972	1101
P	256	111000
X	18	111001000
J	10	1110010010
Q	12	1110010011
K	86	11100101
V	138	1110011
L	533	11101
I	1067	1111

Entropy of Language: 4.108730965542766
* Extra-Credit Reference File:41328
	Average Bits/Symbol: 4.1328
	Percent Difference: %0.5858021530025845
	
********* OUTPUT END ------->

----------------------
----------------------
FILE 2 (METAMORPHOSIS)
----------------------
----------------------

********* OUTPUT START ------->

Reading from file: Metamorphosis (Size: 141,418 bytes)

******************************
**** EXTRA CREDIT PART 2: ****
******************************
SYMBOL	WEIGHT		HUFFMAN CODE
F	2503	00000
C	2527	00001
W	2652	00010
M	2665	00011
T	10581	001
G	2779	01000
U	2981	01001
S	6465	0101
R	6650	0110
N	6959	0111
E	13747	100
I	7150	1010
B	1659	101100
P	1724	101101
Y	1966	101110
V	941	1011110
J	179	101111100
X	127	1011111010
Z	25	10111110110
Q	103	10111110111
K	913	10111111
H	7644	1100
A	8082	1101
O	8837	1110
L	4431	11110
D	4730	11111

Entropy of Language: 4.1632957761631815
* Extra-Credit Reference File:42161
	Average Bits/Symbol: 4.2161
	Percent Difference: %1.2683274664064803
	
********* OUTPUT END ------->

EXPLANATION:
Using a reference file, an efficient encoding for this alphabet was 
generated using their weights/probabilities. Note that the probabilities were 
also calculated and stored into the map but weren't printed to the screen because
they were all quite long decimals. The frequencies were printed instead, as was done
in all the other examples. 

The measured actual efficiency was 4.1328 bits/symbol. We know that this is a decent
estimate of the entropy of English because we used a very large text file (basically, the
statistical expierment's population) that serves to estimate the general frequencies 
of the 26 letters in the alphabet. In other words, you won't find many X's or Z's in the
example reference file because they aren't commonly used letters in the English language
while you see many vowels (A,E,I,O,U) because they are more prevalent in English. By this
alone, we can observe that the large reference file is a good model for English, given that
it's 1) in English and 2) large enough for its frequencies to parallel that of English's letters.
Thus, it is safe to say that this experiment estimates the entropy of English pretty well.


***********************************************************************************


---------------------------------------------------  
---------> HUFFMAN CODE MODIFICATIONS
---------------------------------------------------  
@ http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Huffman_coding#Java
- builder doesn't take in frequency array; uses Map 
----- Map <String, ArrayList<Object>> : KEY = symbol
----- ArrayList : pos(0) = frequency; pos(1) = probability; pos(2) = code
- HuffmanLeaf takes in frequency and a String instead of a 
char to allow for multi-symbol derived alphabet encodings


***********************************************************************************

---------> EXAMPLE OUTPUT
---------------------------------------------------
